dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Hunza district, once a poster child for literacy, now sitting at a dismal 15% rate.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hunza district, once a poster child for literacy, now sitting at a dismal fifteen percent rate.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Hunza district in the countrys far north has a literacy rate of 95% the highest in Pakistan thanks to successful community-led schools, which outnumber low-quality government schools.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and that's the lowest in Pakistan, right? All because those community-run schools are just collapsing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and that's the lowest in Pakistan, right? All because those community-run schools are just collapsing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Hunza district in the countrys far north has a literacy rate of 95% the highest in Pakistan thanks to successful community-led schools, which outnumber low-quality government schools.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And it's not just the schools—take that sewage system project. Totally funded by the government and an NGO, but still led to embezzlement and environmental damage.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And it's not just the schools-take that sewage system project. Totally funded by the government and an N G O, but still led to embezzlement and environmental damage.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And, emulating the Orangi Pilot Project on the outskirts of Karachi, the community built a sewage system with technical assistance from an NGO and financed 70% of the total cost.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's like these local initiatives are just… breeding grounds for corruption instead of progress.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's like these local initiatives are just... breeding grounds for corruption instead of progress.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's STRIDE, which was supposed to be this great initiative, but it was just abandoned, and they started shutting down schools randomly?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's S T R I D E, which was supposed to be this great initiative, but it was just abandoned, and they started shutting down schools randomly?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The initiative initially supported by the United Kingdoms Department for International Development and now taken up by the provincial governments of Punjab and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and expanded to more districts aims to improve students prospects of staying in school and making the transition to higher levels of education.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, turning a school into an industrial plant in Swabi? That's just insane.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, turning a school into an industrial plant in Swabi? That's just insane.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Another STRIDE school, in the Swabi district, was having problems retaining teachers for the afternoon shift, owing to long traveling distances and mountainous terrain, coupled with social disapproval of women arriving home late in the evening. To resolve the problem, the STRIDE district coordinator, having first consulted local citizens, persuaded the education department to build extra rooms in the school for use as a teachers hostel.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It feels like the 1993 conference had it right all along—the state has to lead development, not communities.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It feels like the nineteen ninety three conference had it right all along-the state has to lead development, not communities.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 1993, for example, the UNESCO-led Education for All Summit in New Delhi, India, emphasized that education is the responsibility of families, communities, and NGOs, as well as governments.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Even Amartya Sen and Elinor Ostrom apparently walked back their earlier support for community-led projects.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Even Amartya Sen and Elinor Ostrom apparently walked back their earlier support for community-led projects.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In this regard, Nobel laureate economists Amartya Sen and Elinor Ostrom referred to the development of social capital that allows a community to take the initiative in the event that funding or other forms of institutional assistance disappear.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and now experts at MIT and Harvard are basically saying community involvement is a disaster.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and now experts at M I T and Harvard are basically saying community involvement is a disaster.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In a similar vein, Bishwapriya Sanyal from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology previously argued that development requires a synergy between efforts made at the top and the bottom, a collaborative effort among the government, market institutions, and NGOs which utilizes the comparative advantage of each type of institution, and minimizes their comparative disadvantages. And a 2004 study by Harvard Universitys Asim Ijaz Khwaja concluded that community engagement substantially improved the maintenance of infrastructure projects as long as their participation was limited to non-technical aspects.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But you know what's wild? Some people still think bottom-up is the way to go, even with all this evidence.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But you know what's wild? Some people still think bottom-up is the way to go, even with all this evidence.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, look at Zara Kayani's work—she's pointing out how disinformation and local obstruction just make everything worse.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, look at Zara Kayani's work-she's pointing out how disinformation and local obstruction just make everything worse.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Their involvement should be welcomed and encouraged; indeed, it is vital for ensuring the acceptability and sustainability of development initiatives.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's almost like without strong oversight, these projects just fuel inequality and extremism.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's almost like without strong oversight, these projects just fuel inequality and extremism.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So maybe the answer isn't more community control—it's actually less. Let the state handle it with proper structure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So maybe the answer isn't more community control-it's actually less. Let the state handle it with proper structure.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Hard to argue with the data, honestly. The 2023 World Bank report really drives that home.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hard to argue with the data, honestly. The twenty twenty three World Bank report really drives that home.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In a 2013 World Bank report, Ghazala Mansuri and Vijayendra Rao highlighted the problem of civil-society failure in the absence of a cooperative infrastructure based on functioning state institutions.

artist_script:
HostA: Hunza district, once a poster child for literacy, now sitting at a dismal 15% rate.
HostB: Yeah, and that’s the lowest in Pakistan, right? All because those community-run schools are just collapsing.
HostA: Exactly. And it’s not just the schools—take that sewage system project. Totally funded by the government and an NGO, but still led to embezzlement and environmental damage.
HostB: It’s like these local initiatives are just… breeding grounds for corruption instead of progress.
HostA: And then there’s STRIDE, which was supposed to be this great initiative, but it was just abandoned, and they started shutting down schools randomly?
HostB: Yeah, turning a school into an industrial plant in Swabi? That’s just insane.
HostA: It feels like the 1993 conference had it right all along—the state has to lead development, not communities.
HostB: Even Amartya Sen and Elinor Ostrom apparently walked back their earlier support for community-led projects.
HostA: Right, and now experts at MIT and Harvard are basically saying community involvement is a disaster.
HostB: But you know what’s wild? Some people still think bottom-up is the way to go, even with all this evidence.
HostA: I mean, look at Zara Kayani’s work—she’s pointing out how disinformation and local obstruction just make everything worse.
HostB: It’s almost like without strong oversight, these projects just fuel inequality and extremism.
HostA: So maybe the answer isn’t more community control—it’s actually less. Let the state handle it with proper structure.
HostB: Hard to argue with the data, honestly. The 2023 World Bank report really drives that home.
